results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Paul Goldman
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Acclaimed Australian filmmaker Paul Goldman has directed over 200 music videos including work for Elvis Costello, INXS, Kylie Minogue, Crowded House and Silverchair. Paul also directed seminal Australian films like ‘Australian Rules’ and ‘Suburban Mayhem’. In this inverview, Paul talks candidly about his early music videos for Nick Cave’s ‘The Birthday Party’ and ‘The Reels’.

Created as part of “Spectacle : The Music Video Exhibition” 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014. ACMI Digital Programs worked with Exhibitions to interview five Australian directors featured in the exhibition about the art and techniques of music video production.

results.title: Among the Hardwoods
results.creator_credit: Lyn Maplestone and Commonwealth of Australia
results.brief_description: An earlier silent version of this film was made in 1927 as part of the ‘Know Your Own Country’ series by renowned pioneer cinematographer Lacey Percival. In mid-1936 Bert Ive and a sound recordist revisited the Pemberton region of south-west Western Australia where they filmed and also recorded natural sounds from the forest. Whilst this re-edited film was half the length of the original, Ive’s director Lyn Maplestone created greater impact by lingering on the sights and sounds of logging trees in the Jarrah and Karri forests. The film focuses on the atmosphere of the forest as it was irrevocably changed by the axe and saw of the loggers. Scenes shot for the silent version (but not always used) can also be seen being processed and screened in ‘Telling the World’ (1929). Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection.

results.title: In conversation with Chris Dercon and Kaat Debo
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
This free talk was held at ACMI on 17 July 2013 to celebrate two exhibitions, ACMI’s ‘Hollywood Costume’ and RMIT University Design Hub’s ‘Walter Van Beirendonck; Dream the World Awake’.

Chris Dercon, director of London’s Tate Modern, and Kaat Debo, director/curator at Mode Museum in Antwerp, discussed the particulars of exhibiting fashion and costume, and explored the dialogue between art and fashion.

They investigated the ways a curator can animate clothes through multisensory and multimedia experiences, Dercon and Debo looked at the approaches taken by curators, identifying interesting narratives for exhibiting garments and took the audience behind-the-seams of fashion and costume exhibiting.

results.title: Hollywood Costume: What is Costume Design? with Prof. D. Nadoolman Landis
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In a special event held at ACMI as part of the ‘Hollywood Costume’ exhibition, curator Professor Deborah Nadoolman Landis introduced the art of costume design and discussed its role in cinematic storytelling.
Landis, an Oscar®-nominated Hollywood costume designer (‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’, ‘The Blues Brothers’, Michael Jackson’s ‘Thriller’) is also the author of ‘Hollywood Costume’ (2012), the prize-winning exhibition catalogue, and ‘Hollywood Sketchbook: A Century of Costume Illustration’ (2012) among many other volumes.
Landis received her Ph.D. from the Royal College of Art in London and is the Founding Director of the David C. Copley Center for Costume Design at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television.

results.title: An Evening with Shaun Tan
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
To celebrate the exhibition ‘Shaun Tan’s The Lost Thing: From Book to Film’ a special evening with the Oscar®-winning animator, author and illustrator, Shaun Tan was held on 24 July 2013. He discussed the making of the exhibition, talked about his body of work and shared insights into his creative processes.
Shaun’s books, including ‘The Rabbits’, ‘The Red Tree’ and the acclaimed graphic novel ‘The Arrival’, have been widely translated and enjoyed by readers of all ages. His work as a feature film concept artist can be seen in films like ‘Wall-E’ (2008) and his Academy Award®-winning animated short ‘The Lost Thing’, which he also wrote and co-directed.
In 2011, Shaun received the prestigious Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award in Sweden. His attraction to children’s stories with confronting or puzzling ideas is reflected in his work, which encourages dialogue between adult readers and younger listeners.

results.title: The Calling
results.creator_credit: Angelica Mesiti, Jodie Passmore, Bridget Ikin and Felix Media
results.credit_line:
Angelica Mesiti
Three channel video installation, digital video, sound, 35:36 mins.
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection
Courtesy the artist and Anna Schwartz Gallery
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, three channel video, projection, colour and audio.
results.brief_description:
‘The Calling’ is a three-channel video installation that focuses on whistling languages, ancient forms of non-verbal communication which are still used in 2013 to communicate in isolated and difficult landscapes.

To conduct research for ‘The Calling’, artist Angelica Mesiti travelled to the village of Kuskoy in Northern Turkey, the island of La Gomera in The Canary Islands and the Island of Evia in Greece where whistling languages are all still in use.

For these communities, whistling languages are in a process of transformation from their traditional use as tools for communication across vast lands into tourist attractions and cultural artefacts and are being taught to local school children.

‘The Calling’ is a poignant exploration of ancient human traditions evolving and adapting to the modern world. The work speaks to the tenacity and creativity of traditional cultures in the face of globalisation, technological progress and environmental flux.

Angelica Mesiti was the winner of the inaugural Ian Potter Moving Image Commission.

results.title: The Estate
results.creator_credit: Toby Conway-Hughes, Caswell Coggins, Mike Carr, Balletboyz, Crossfire and Channel 4
results.brief_description: A short dance piece set in an English housing estate. The choreography is loosely based on the idea of vultures circling a dying animal, feeling their excitement and anticipation as they gather to feed, waiting for the moment to strike.

results.title: Shaun Tan's The Lost Thing: From book to film. The Interviews
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Set in a city overrun by bureaucracy, Shaun Tan’s picture book ‘The Lost Thing’ tells the story of a boy who befriends a strange creature that doesn’t appear to fit in any of the available pigeon holes.
Melbourne-based production company Passion Pictures Australia invited Shaun to direct an animated version of ‘The Lost Thing’, and several years later, the Oscar®-winning short film emerged.
The ACMI exhibition ‘Shaun Tan’s The Lost Thing: From book to film’(showing in Gallery Two from 16th July 2013 to 19th January 2014), features Shaun’s exquisite original drawings and working sketches alongside exclusive footage of the animators and sound artists, demonstrating how the drawings were brought to life on screen with movement, sound effects, music and narration.
These eight interview segments are each based on a particular production process in the making of ‘The Lost Thing’.
The eight segments feature interviews with Shaun Tan (writer/co director), Sophie Byrne (producer), Tom Bryant (3D artist), Leo Baker (animator), John Kassab (sound designer) and Michael Yezerski (composer).
In addition to the interviews, there is a wealth of ‘behind-the-scenes’ footage, rough drafts of designs and animation wireframes from the very early stages of production.
